context: <b5_0>Due to extreme variation in elevation<b5_0/>, <a0_0>great variation<a0_0/> occurs in the climatic conditions of Himachal . The climate <a1_0>varies <b8_0>from hot and subhumid tropical<a1_0/> in the southern tracts to, with more elevation, cold, alpine, and glacial in the northern and eastern mountain ranges<b8_0/>. The state has areas like Dharamsala that receive very heavy rainfall, as well as those like Lahaul and Spiti that are cold and almost rainless. Broadly, Himachal experiences three seasons: <a2_0><b6_0>summer, winter, and rainy season<b6_0/><a2_0/>. Summer lasts <b7_0>from <a3_0>mid-April till the end of June<b7_0/><a3_0/> and most parts become <b9_0>very hot<b9_0/> (except in the alpine zone which experiences a mild summer) with the average temperature ranging from 28 to 32 °C (82 to 90 °F). Winter lasts from <a4_0>late November till mid March.<a4_0/> Snowfall is common in alpine tracts (generally above 2,200 metres (7,218 ft) i.e. in the higher and trans-Himalayan region).
